title: 115_hr6989
content: SECTION 1. RESTRICTING FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO VERIFIED CITIZENS. Restriction on Federal assistance benefits: An individual must meet citizenship requirements to be eligible for assistance under any Federal assistance program. The citizenship requirement for individuals receiving Federal assistance benefits includes an attestation and citizenship verification. An individual must meet these requirements to be eligible for assistance under any Federal program. Individual receiving Federal assistance benefits must provide a written declaration confirming their US citizenship. They also need to verify their citizenship with satisfactory documentary evidence when applying for benefits. The Social Security Act requires individuals applying for benefits to provide proof of US citizenship or nationality, along with a photographic identity document and their name and social security account number for verification. The individual must provide proof of citizenship or nationality, along with a photographic identity document, social security account number, and other information to receive Federal assistance benefits. The individual must provide proof of citizenship or nationality, along with a photographic identity document and social security number for confirmation through the Social Security Administration. The Commissioner compares information submitted by an entity with records maintained to confirm the validity of the number and citizenship status. The entity may transmit the individual's name, social security number, and identity information for confirmation through the Department of Homeland Security. The individual must submit identifying information to the Secretary of Homeland Security for confirmation. The Secretary will then confirm or deny the information provided by the entity regarding the individual's records. The Department of Homeland Security verifies citizenship status through the SAVE program, requiring individuals to provide identity information for confirmation. If documentary evidence is not provided or citizenship is not confirmed, notice is given. The Department of Homeland Security verifies citizenship status through the SAVE program, requiring individuals to provide identity information for confirmation. If citizenship is not confirmed, the entity processing the application for Federal assistance benefit must notify the individual of their ineligibility and provide an opportunity to appeal the determination. Additionally, the head of any federal department or agency administering a benefit program must provide an appeals process for individuals deemed ineligible for federal assistance benefits. In this section, the term "national" refers to a national of the United States. For Federal assistance benefits, children or their parents meeting citizenship requirements are eligible. Household or family units are also eligible if any member meets the citizenship requirement. Individuals treated as household or family members must meet citizenship requirements for benefits, with exceptions for elderly individuals in supportive housing programs. The Affordable Housing Act requires disabled individuals in a household to meet citizenship requirements for Federal assistance benefits. Once the requirement is met, it continues as long as the individual remains eligible. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget can issue regulations to implement this section. The Director must specify the declaration form and verification process for citizenship within 30 days of the Act's enactment, based on existing forms and processes. The provisions of this section supersede any laws related to eligibility for Federal assistance based on citizenship, nationality, or immigration status, unless determined more restrictive by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Office of Management and Budget can disqualify entities from providing Federal assistance benefits if they repeatedly fail to meet citizenship requirements or submit required information. The Inspector General of each Federal department must monitor program compliance and report regularly. The program requires regular compliance reports from entities providing benefits under the Federal assistance program. The term "Federal assistance program" includes any provision of Federal law authorizing benefits based on income or resources. The effective date for eligibility determinations under this program is one year after the enactment of the Act. The Act requires individuals to meet citizenship requirements within 2 years of its enactment to remain eligible for Federal assistance benefits.
